{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3608783,"name":"Rustomac","username":"Rustomac","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/85e7bf/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-01T14:26:33.011Z","cooked":"

Our team has always had issues trying to get accurate holes with our current tube jig setup and we will have time and money this off-season to improve our setup. We’d like to get something that’s as fool proof as possible. What are your thoughts on the WCP tube jig? Any things to consider before we make the purchase? Any concerns with bearing alignment if the tube parallelograms due to uneven/over clamping? This would go on our Omio X8. Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-05-01T14:26:33.011Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":57,"reads":801,"readers_count":800,"score":505.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501000,"topic_slug":"considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it","display_username":"Rustomac","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12113,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it/501000/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3608784,"name":"","username":"ConnorG","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/65b543/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-01T14:28:42.778Z","cooked":"

It’s great

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-05-01T14:28:42.778Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":800,"readers_count":799,"score":235.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":501000,"topic_slug":"considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73728,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it/501000/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3608840,"name":"Sam Viesselman","username":"samviesselman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/samviesselman/{size}/237998_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-01T15:26:28.812Z","cooked":"

Every piece of tubing on our robot was done on our WCP Tube Jig this year, and we loved it. We had a couple of the cam bolts strip on the clamps, but that was easily resolved by training up the students to not overtighten.

We looked at building our own but after factoring in the materials and time savings, it was hard to beat just buying it from WCP.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-05-01T15:26:44.862Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":734,"readers_count":733,"score":216.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":501000,"topic_slug":"considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it","display_username":"Sam Viesselman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37087,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it/501000/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3609095,"name":"Stewart Riley","username":"Strategic","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/strategic/{size}/10157_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-01T20:02:03.238Z","cooked":"

We’ve had ours for a few years now and can say it’s still doing excellent work. We use it all the time, both for specific machining (bearing holes, precise mounting holes, etc.) and for weight pocketing. You should buy extra cam bolts and clamp blocks, they do wear out eventually, but that’s the extent of any spare parts or maintenance you need to do. Extremely reliable and accurate, plus easy to use is our final judgement on it.

We havent but id be interested. does anyone know if this can be set up on routers other than the Oimo? it looks like it can be put into tracks assuming the router has them but its hard to tell just by looking at one image. Securing tubing has been a challenge in some applications and a secure Jig would be great to have

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-05-06T18:02:31.076Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":346,"readers_count":345,"score":104.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":501000,"topic_slug":"considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it","display_username":"David B","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7167,"username":"tyron256","name":"Saber_8871","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyron256/{size}/177261_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39555,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"David, Mentor FRC 6004/4795"},"post_url":"/t/considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it/501000/7","custom_user_title":"David, Mentor FRC 6004/4795","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3614513,"name":"Tom Praisner","username":"TJP1699","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjp1699/{size}/216696_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-07T00:14:37.684Z","cooked":"

We purchased a Shapeoko 5 Pro 48" x 48" with the 700W spindle this past summer and love it! It has been an amazing machine for us so far. We have cut a lot of aluminum on it this past season, including three belly pans roughly 30" x 30". The large bed size allows us to keep a couple of different materials mounted for quick cuts.

Regarding tubing jigs, we machined our own from aluminum bar stock and we simply use the Shapeoko Tiger Claw clamps to hold the tubing against our tubing “jig.”

Also, we have settled on an effective and neat arrangement for coolant/lubrication in using an airbrush compressor, with an inexpensive mister from Amazon, running 70% isopropyl alcohol. We run this mister in conjunction with our Shapeoko dust boot and a Stealthsonic Dewalt shop vac. There is nearly nothing to clean up after a day of routing and we can carry on conversations next to the router while using it. Here is a link to our OA build blog this year, showing our robot and many of the parts we routed on our Shapeoko.

image1920×1280 234 KB

1699 Robocats | 2025 Build Thread FRC Open Alliance
Some more details about our robot with an articulated elevator, wrist, and grabber: Our robot, “Carl” weighs just under 100 lbs. We added about 14 lbs of ballast to help stabilize him, bringing our final weight to 114 lbs. The elevator employs SDS elevator blocks and tube plugs Anodized 2x1 pre-drilled 1/16" wall thickness tubing. Note, the anodization has not worn off, in part because it hardens the surface of the aluminum… plus, it looks sweet! Internal elevator rigging with 1/8" Dyneema c…

TJP1699:

Also, we have settled on an effective and neat arrangement for coolant/lubrication in using an airbrush compressor, with an inexpensive mister from Amazon, running 70% isopropyl alcohol.

I would love to hear more about the airbrush pump/mister combo in this application. We have a shapeoko 3xxl, and have been relying on manually sprayed WD40, which works fine but eventually goops up our spoilboard prematurely and it’s not awesome with the “sweepy” dust extractor, especially when doing a high volume cut like pocketing.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-05-07T17:32:39.729Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":30.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":501000,"topic_slug":"considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it","display_username":"David B","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44427,"username":"knightscape","name":"Sam Knight","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/knightscape/{size}/137599_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":39555,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"David, Mentor FRC 6004/4795"},"post_url":"/t/considering-the-wcp-tube-jig-wcp-0347-how-do-you-like-it/501000/10","custom_user_title":"David, Mentor FRC 6004/4795","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3616351,"name":"Tom Praisner","username":"TJP1699","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tjp1699/{size}/216696_2.png","created_at":"2025-05-07T22:57:39.073Z","cooked":"

Below are the details for the compressor, mister, and tubing we used for our setup… all purchased from Amazon. Please note, this compressor is not able to clear chips like shop air. But it does a fine job of moving them up and out of cuts while delivering the coolant mist. The 70% isopropyl alcohol (ISA) / 30% water mist evaporates very quickly and does not make the chips stick to the cut. This approach keeps the aluminum cool to the touch throughout the cut. Using a “Sweepy” with our aforementioned shop vac, with the mister nozzle pushed through the bristles of the Sweepy dust boot (see last image), eliminates any chip binding. There is also essentially no need for any clean up after machining. It is sweet how simple and cost-effective this setup is… not chips flying all over the place, no problems with our spoil board getting all swollen, super quiet compressor, super quiet shop vac, no cleanup.

The last image shows our router just after cutting the belly pan for our bot this season. There has been no cleanup prior to taking this picture In this image you can see how we have a small reservoir of ISA mounted right on the z-axis with a short tube running to our mister. This ISA bottle has a tight fitting cap so ISA does not get splashed onto our spindle. It holds enough ISA for about an hour of cutting.

TIMBERTECH Airbrush Compressor AS18-2, Basic Mini Compressor

OriGlam Mist Coolant Lubrication Spray System

TAILONZ PNEUMATIC Black 8mm or 5/16 OD 5mm ID Polyurethane PU Air Hose Pipe Tube Kit 10 Meter

IMG_72391920×1440 283 KB
